Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CS in Parallel: Scaling an Incremental Modular Approach to Injecting Parallel Computing Throughout CS Curricula

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The shift to parallel computing, including multi-core processors, cloud computing, and heterogeneous systems, has induced a workforce development crisis for computer science (CS) education. This project addresses how crowded CS curricula, traditionally structured around sequential (non-parallel) computing, can be changed to effectively incorporate the rapidly-evolving body of parallelism knowledge.

Saint Olaf College, Calvin College and Macalester College are demonstrating how colleges and universities can insert short (one- to three-day) teaching modules on parallel computing into their courses through self-contained units that present conceptual principles and reinforce them by hands-on experience and follow-up exercises. New modules that incorporate emerging curricular recommendations, relevant applications to other fields, and parallel design patterns are under development. Parallelism is infused incrementally throughout the CS curriculum. Having developed this modular strategy in a predecessor CCLI Type I grant, this project demonstrates the scalability of this approach to other universities and colleges by targeting two geographical regions with workshops and follow-up adopter support.

Other project activities reward participants for creating new modules, promote the national dissemination of this modular approach through conference workshops and presentations, and expand existing synergistic partnerships between CSinParallel.org and related efforts in industry, academia, and professional organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CSinParallel project seeks to address the emerging challenges and opportunities of parallel and distributed computing (PDC) in computer science (CS) undergraduate education.  For example, nearly all computers and mobile devices now incorporate a form of parallel computing called multi-core hardware, in which each computing unit contains multiple circuits for carrying out computer instructions simultaneously.  Also, cloud computing is a form of distributed computing, where multiple separate computers interact over a network in order to perform a computation.  PDC has become ubiquitous over the past ten years, but computer science curricula traditionally focused on single-core computations on a single computer.  CSinParallel provides learning strategies for incrementally adding PDC to multiple courses throughout a college’s undergraduate CS curriculum, in order to prepare the computing workforce for the conceptual principles, technical considerations, and potential benefits of the parallel and distributed computing that is now available everywhere.  

CSinParallel provides brief (1-3 class days) modular learning materials that present conceptual principles of PDC reinforced through hands-on experience, which modules are self-contained and can be used flexibly in wide-ranging curricular contexts.  These materials can be taught on many available PDC computing platforms, and can be quickly adapted for emerging developments in PDC hardware and software, as well as for new strategies for delivering PDC education.

This project produced new modular teaching materials that focus on parallel programming patterns, which constitute a framework of effective and reusable problem-solving strategies discovered and developed in industry, and which provide a head-start for CS undergraduates creating PDC applications, taking advantage of the wisdom of industry experience.  Other new modules focus on exemplar applications that feature realistic uses of PDC in other fields, which provide motivation for learning about PDC, engage students with applications that make a difference in people’s lives, illustrate issues that arise when concepts and technologies meet actual applications, and serve as examples for encountering and comparing multiple PDC technologies.  Patterns and exemplars, presented hands-on in the context of various PDC technologies, have come to form the basis for our series of part-day workshops for faculty and students delivered at national meetings, and for a pilot series of on-site multi-day regional workshops for faculty conducted in the Southwest, Pacific Northwest, Chicago area, and East Coast.  The on-site regional workshops can potentially be scaled to a network of sustainable series of such workshops in many regions.  To support workshops and faculty adopters, we developed new PDC computational platforms focused on learning, including an emerging, affordable, and scalable platform that uses Raspberry Pi single-board computers. Our project also created TSGL, a graphical visualization tool for teaching PDC concepts through observing parallel computations in real time. All teaching and workshop materials are available at the CSinParallel.org website.

This project’s activities contribute progress toward a number of intended medium- and long-term outcomes, including integration of PDC into undergraduate CS courses and institutional curricula (aligning with recent national curricular recommendations), developing PDC habits of mind and effective pattern-based problem solving among CS students (and ultimately the computing workforce), awareness of realistic and effective applications of PDC in research and industry, incorporation of industry PDC advances into undergraduate education, achievement of accelerated curricular change through affordable incremental interventions within existing courses, and access to PDC principles, experience, and technology for members of underrepresented groups.

The most immediate impact of this CSinParallel project is to address the challenges and opportunities presented by PDC in the undergraduate CS curriculum, as indicated above.  Our incremental modular strategy provides both breadth and depth in PDC education, taking advantage of proven effective educational strategies including hands-on active learning and a spiral approach to education.  But this project also impacts education in other STEM disciplines, whose students gain exposure to PDC concepts and technologies in introductory CS courses that include CSinParallel modules. Exemplar modules that present applications in STEM fields create additional connections and motivation for learning PDC.  Our outreach through workshops to a tribal college, HBCUs, and the Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing provides diverse students, faculty, and institutions with access to emerging and potent PDC technologies. Exposure through CSinParallel materials to pattern-based problem solving, enduring principles of PDC, and current PDC technologies, help CS undergraduates to meet the challenges of adapting to new PDC technologies and practices which are themselves in flux, ultimately contributing to a versatile technology workforce.  Since the US is producing far fewer CS graduates than the workforce demands, producing CS graduates who already know about forward-looking PDC technologies and concepts enables US companies to compete on the basis of high-quality problem solving savvy and adaptability throughout their careers. Finally, CSinParallel’s incremental, modular approach to rapid curricular introduction of PDC in CS undergraduate curricula serves as a model for rapid curricular change in other fields within and outside of CS, indicating a reusable strategy for large-scale transformations in undergraduate education.
